item.title: US jobs report spurs stocks
item.description: US stocks hit their highest levels since October after a better-than-expected employment report buttressed hopes that the recession was nearing an end

item.title: Swine flu fears spawn bogus cures
item.description: Shampoo made with ionic silver, bottles of “free-radical quenchers” and a $2,995 device called the “photon genie” have all fallen foul of US regulators ­battling modern-day snake-oil marketing spawned by the ­global swine flu pandemic

item.title: AIG reports first quarterly profit since 2007
item.description: AIG reported its first profit in seven quarters, helped by large accounting gains in a partial reversal of the huge mark-to-market losses that forced the US government to rescue the stricken insurer last year

item.title: Beijing orders state banks to slow loans
item.description: China’s central bank has told the largest state-controlled banks to slow the pace of new lending, say people familiar with the matter, after new loan volume in the first half tripled from same period a year earlier

item.title: Rivals sceptical of Murdoch’s charging plan
item.description: Rupert Murdoch’s pledge to charge for online content from all his news outlets has been met with scepticism from some rivals, even as they attempt to find their own alternatives to a broken business model

item.title: Cyber-attacks ‘aimed at Georgia blogger’
item.description: The cyber-attacks that felled popular internet messaging service Twitter and blogging platform LiveJournal this week were apparently aimed at silencing a single person who had been posting comments critical of Russian activity in the country of Georgia, another of the victimised companies and an outside security expert said

item.title: UBS in fresh DoJ deal delay
item.description: UBS and the US Department of Justice failed to reach agreement on an out-of-court settlement of their battle over access to client names, but said they hoped to have a deal by the middle of next week.

item.title: Medvedev orders probe into state companies
item.description: Dmitry Medvedev has ordered a probe into Russia’s state-owned companies as pressure mounts over the government’s handling of the economy that shrank 10 per cent in the first half of the year

item.title: Taliban leader is dead, says Pakistan
item.description: Pakistan’s foreign minister said he believed Baitullah Mehsud, the country’s Taliban leader, had been killed, ending almost 48 hours of speculation over the fate of the country’s most wanted man

item.title: German exports show unexpected surge
item.description: German exports have swung back to solid growth, surging by 7 per cent in June, according to data on Friday that raised hopes of an early end to the country’s recession
